Almost feel like i am glad I had the cancer LOL. If anyone is trying to debate weather to have surgery or chemicals to battle this cancer, I will be more than happy to answer any question you may have. Any one that had surgery and doesn't at less look into a implant is not being fair to their selves. This is the greatest invention by man.

Posts.Content: MJ8 Taker it easy, he has caught it early. I was 45 when this exact thing happen to me. 12 years late it was removed. I am sure you will have a bunch of guy that will add a lot more but if he had a MRI and nothing was detected, I don't think I would have a biopsy yet. It was 2004 I was at the Mayo clinic and they could not find it with a biopsy.Again in 2010 nothing found in the biopsy. 2015 they did a MRI and this a ultrasound guided biopsy and Bingo I was Just a G6. He has caught it so early that he is a great candidate for the HIFU, if he has the means to pay for it. Most insurance does not pay for it. Remember lot of things can cause that PSA level to go up besides cancer. even riding a bike or sex days before the PSA was taken

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate These statistics from the American Cancer Society should help you calm down. Only 2 percent of the men diagnosed now with prostate cancer will die from prostate cancer within 10 years. Only 5 percent will die from prostate cancer in 15 years. And, treatments are becoming more effective with time. https://www.cancer.org/cancer/prosta...val-rates.html Now, that said, moving ahead with a biopsy and other diagnostic work is essential to know if he has cancer, and to ensure that he has the best odds to beat it. ASAdovocate, Why would you think he needs a biopsy if they did a MRI and found nothing? Those biopsies are hit and miss to start with. I just wish I had the MRI option when I first had my elevated PSA Just asking

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Tybeeman. Could you check your lab reports -- I'm not understanding all those "<" signs through 2015. I don't think they should be there. It's reasonable that your recent <0.01 less-than signs are correct -- it would mean that the PSA test you had doesn't measure below 0.01, so your exact value can't be further determined. Do check whether your last result was indeed <0.03 and not 0.03. If it was <0.03, you can't deduce anything, because your PSA could still be <0.1. However, if your last test was 0.3, you should discuss it with your doc and perhaps retest to see if it is accurate and therefore a true increase. Be sure to look at (and request if necessary) the original results from the lab doing the test. Also, be sure to keep testing with the same test from the same lab. Didn't notice that it is just .03

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another My docs office changed tests on me. It went from <.01 to <0.06. That generated some phone calls. They changed tests. I now test through LabQuest to <.02. My local health service can not/will not test below 0.06. I thought I was helping by giving them the testing business. Mea culpa. It's not their model. They were unclear in the language and options. They called the 0.02 limit ultrasensitive. Lesson learned, your primary is good for screening. Go throuh your urologist/MO/RO and a national lab for post treatment testing. Yes I just checked this was done by a different lab All my others have been done by Labcorp. That was a little scare

Posts.Content: I would have to say I am lucky on all fronts that I have been in the zero club now for 16 months. The cancer was contained in the prostate. I got good consistency back by 3 months. Just a little leakage on occasions that can hardly be noticed at all. I have stayed on a strict therapy of vacuum pumping every night and taking Cialis daily. No luck with getting an erection. I have tried the injection with no luck. They are just too painful for hours afterwards even if I get a erection. An implant is my only option left. I have it scheduled for July 20th. I think I am more nervous about this then my RP. I realize they say to wait a year, but I am getting nothing and it is very depressing. To all you guys out there that are just now finding out you have PC. Make sure you have support on the erection problem you may face. Right now you are thinking about getting rid of the cancer. Once you make the decision find someone that will help you with depression. It can be tough on some of us. Again I am blessed I am in the zero club, that is goal number one.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LetsDoThis Hi Everyone, Has anyone ever experienced a receding testosterone level over 18 months after your last Lupron injection? (Last Lupron shot was a 3 month and only had 2 total.) Over the last few months my husband has been experience painful breasts....mainly when he rolls over or something pushes against them. (He did not experience this during the Lupron Treatment.) He had his regular Oncologist appointment this past week and he says it's most likely gynecomastia. (Good news, is that his PSA has been <.01 since treatment!) He then had him get blood work to see what testosterone level is currently at. We just got results back from the portal and the testosterone is receding for some reason. So his last Lupron (3 month) was given in November 2015. Last radiation was mid-December 2015. (Also had prostate out in March 2015) His Testosterone Results: (Standard range according to the hospital portal is 249-836 ng/dl) 5/13/16: 15 8/30/16: 176 11/15/16: 214 5/16/17: 169 We are still waiting to hear back from the oncologist on the result but during the appointment he said it wouldn't be normal for Testosterone to go backwards at this point. I can't seem to find any info on the testosterone climbing back to normal and then receding again. Of course the oncologist said (while we were chatting before this latest test result) that giving him testosterone is not an option -- as that could cause issues with any dormant cancer cells. But there are a lot of medical problems associated with low T levels too. He's had blood in his urine since he finished treatment. He's had (1) Cysto and nothing abnormal noted so they chalked it up to be part of the irritated bladder from the surgery/radiation, etc. He's been in the ER for kidney stones 3x since August. The most recent within 2 a month period. And at each cat scan they don't show any additional stone. So the last one formed quite quickly, within 2 months. Last Cat Scan Kidney also enlarged -- which wasn't an issue the first two stones. Going to see a Kidney Stone specialist on Monday....they say probably unrelated the prostate cancer and treatment...but I don't know....something just feels like it doesn't add up. And now his blood pressure is elevated too. His bladder control is very good. ED still pretty much sucks. He has a feeling there is something more going on although he's trying to stay positive. But he just feels crappy. He's working and trying to live a normal life. Just wondered if anyone has had the testosterone receding again or any input? Thanks guys! Gina Gina I had RP in February of 2016 at the 3 month test I asked if they would also check my testosterone, I just felt tired all the time and no sex drive at all. My testosterone level was at 59. The doctor put me on testosterone injects that day. I asked him wasn't it early to start testosterone this early after surgery and he said it no that I need to be at less 600. If i was to leave it low I would have no sex drive to think about he also said he wanted to keep me on watch every 3 months for a few years until I stayed zero. I am 58 years old and am glad he did. But now I have a sex drive with no erection so that part is not fun. I would get a second opinion. I did and both my surgeon and my local urologist agreed that they wanted the testosterone level at 600. One side note, at over 50 years old they did not want me on estrogen blocker. Both urologist and the cardiologist said the a high level of estrogen is good for the heart

Posts.Title: Reclinging Testosterone 18 months AFTER last Lupron? And also Multiple Kidney stones

Posts.Content: Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. I was in about the same place as you in February of 2016 but 10 years younger. I had surgery. My advice to would would be there are really the big 3 Cancer, inconsistency and sex. How important is sex to you? If you are a once a week planed sex guy then if you have it removed there are injection that work for a lot of people. Inconsistency is another thing to consider. I think for most of us we got that back. The days of have to wear a dipper the rest of your life is slim. You may need a pad which to some people is a big deal. I had no problem with it after 2 months a had a slim pad that I hardly knew was in my underwear. Then there is the cancer. Unless you remove it, it will always be there in some type of state. I just couldn't live knowing that once day I will get a PSA at a high level and then be told that it can't remove it or it will be a high risk savage removal. The one small thing that you may not be worried about. with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hello Tybeeman, it is very frustrating indeed and I am sure the implant will be fine. Just wanted to say that for me it took two years to get a decent erection. However I did have some signs of life before that. And now after 28 months it is ok again. I don´t really know where I am going with this all I am saying is that it can take a long time to make it work again. Well I have done the rounds and interviewed 3 urologist. They all said I would never get back to where I was and my erection will be limited. I had a very active sex life leading up to RP 4 to 5 times a week. It is hell seeing a naked woman you love get in the bed and you get excite with no sign of an erection. I don't want to knock anyone but some guys sex is not a big deal, but the ones of us that it is a big deal they need to be prepared mentally for the 18 months to a year it takes to get it back

Posts.Title: Curious to what everyones testosterone levels are

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by murphyj My current stats and confusing. 43 years old. PSA 3.9. Biopsy 3+3 G6 with 2 out of 12 cores positive. Less then 10% total volume. Endo Coil MRI didnt detect the cancer. I have NO INTEREST IN RP DaVinci and the SE. But Im confused how a biopsy says 1 thing and the MRI detects nothing? Pretty uncomfortable procedure to find nothing. Im at a Crossroads. Looking seriously at AS but surgeons recommends surgery. He states its very low risk but looking at my stats Im a Ideal AS player here I think. Why have that surgery at 43... That is a tough one. but i was in your shoes at the age of 45. i did AS till i had it removed at 56. looking back i wish i would have done it sooner. At your age it will need to come out unless HIFU becomes insurable. Right now you are a great candidate but you would have to pay cash for it.

Posts.Title: Finding the right doctor for 3T MRI + question on lycopene

Posts.Content: Boy that is a long post LOL. I am a bad reader and a worst writer so pardon my bad writing skills. I was in about the same place as you in February of 2016 but 10 years younger. I had surgery. My advice to would would be there are really the big 3 Cancer, inconsistency and sex. How important is sex to you? If you are a once a week planed sex guy then if you have it removed there are injection that work for a lot of people. Inconsistency is another thing to consider. I think for most of us we got that back. The days of have to wear a dipper the rest of your life is slim. You may need a pad which to some people is a big deal. I had no problem with it after 2 months a had a slim pad that I hardly knew was in my underwear. Then there is the cancer. Unless you remove it, it will always be there in some type of state. I just couldn't live knowing that once day I will get a PSA at a high level and then be told that it can't remove it or it will be a high risk savage removal. The one small thing that you may not be worried about. with any radiation you will almost always have some type of recurrence in 20 years. that make you 87. At 56 I would be 76. My dad was 95 when he died and my mother is still alive at 93. I did want to deal with it at 76.

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: It has been 10 months since my robotic radical prostatectomy. I have had my consistency back since the 3rd month, with just a little leakage, mainly when I drink. Now no problem at all. Have not had an erection yet but I am taking Cialis daily and triple dose twice a week. Last night I woke up with a nocturnal erection. Was wondering if anyone else has experience this and could this be a sign that I will be getting my erections back. It is a long process and I am sure most of you know I am very anxious. I started taking injections 6 months ago, with very little luck. I am on my 4th mix and now they are sending me another. If I do get an erection it hurts too bad to have an orgasm. Has anyone had the same problem? I have shot a lot of needles not to have any erections. Frustrating

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wilde Hi Tybeeman, If you get erections during night that is a very good sign and it shows that you are healing. Also this is important to avoid the dreaded shrinkage...Give it some time, it will come back. You are one year a head of me I hope you are doing well. I have been using the pump for therapy for shrinkage. My regular urologist told me it was voo doo but I feel it has really helped. Thanks for your comment

Posts.Title: Inflatable Penile Prostheses (Implants)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate A lady with my travel group here in Bukhara, Uzbekistan fell while exiting her shower and broke her wrist. After the front desk was notified, a doctor and nurse promptly came to her room and evaluated her. They did some injections to the injury, and called for an ambulance. A few minutes later, she was at a hospital, had X-rays and saw a surgeon, who reset her bones. A plaster cast was made, and she was released at her insistence, to join today’s tour. She was given pain medication. Total time was about 90 minutes from accident to release. Cost? There is no cost for medical care in Uzbekistan. Our group of Americans and Canadians were amazed. Free AND fast??? This is a third world Soviet-style nation, and there is much to criticize about the government’s heavy control of everything. But, there are bright spots in every gray scene, and today, health care was Uzbekistan’s shining example. Uzbekistan! You are really not going to compare their health care to the US. Please. How many research hospitals are in Uzbekistan?

I was 57 and had sex 4 to 5 time s week. even if I could get to once a week I would not be happy

Posts.Title: 14 months out for prostate surgery

Posts.Content: I healed well and quick, was back at my desk 6 days after surgery. Constancy is better now than it was before the surgery. I had a lot of problems with my enlarged prostrate. Start back with a heavy work out in the gym and have only had a few dips on some abs work out. Erections, I have done the 14 months of pumping and daily Cialis. Started injections 6 months ago and have about 30% success with that but it is still painful and does not last long. Doctor still trying to change up the mix. Had an appointment with my local urologist last week and he said at this point, the likely hood of me getting my normal erections even with the pills is not good being that I have only had a few nocturnal erections. I am sure everyone on here that is married have, in their eyes, a beautiful wife. I got one that turns everyones head. To have her walking around me all-day and me getting sexual aroused all the time is very frustrating. At what month post-surgery will I know it is not coming back? Before surgery I had sex 4 to 5 time a week. I am now where I am lucky to be successful having it work once a week, but even then, a lot of pain for a few hours after injecting. At what point should I start considering an Implant? I know I made the right decision because I am in the zero club and Doctor Patel along with my local urologist was so sure he got everything he put me on testosterone therapy at the 3-month mark. Which makes feel a hell of a lot better but of course horny as hell which is the double edge sword
